0,1 ORG|1,2 Justice:Sue|0,2 r_Defendant
0,1 ORG|1,2 Justice:Sue|0,2 r_Defendant

Re : Dell sued for " bait and switch " and false promises
2,3 ORG|3,4 Justice:Sue|2,4 r_Defendant
2,3 ORG|3,4 Justice:Sue|2,4 r_Defendant

Then there was the class action suit against Gateway brought by some Philadelphia lawyers a number of years ago .
8,9 ORG|12,13 GPE|13,14 PER|6,7 Justice:Sue|6,9 Defendant|6,14 Plaintiff
8,9 ORG|12,13 GPE|13,14 PER|6,7 Justice:Sue|6,9 Defendant|6,14 Plaintiff

Gateway advertised and stickered many of its 486 computers as " Pentium Ready ", meaning that a special Type 3 ZIF socket Pentium OverDrive could be installed and run .
0,1 ORG|6,7 ORG
0,1 ORG|6,7 ORG

Micronics designed the motherboards used by Gateway , and the basis of the design was a prototype Pentium OverDrive with an internal write - through cache , a more conservative cache design .
0,1 ORG|6,7 ORG
0,1 ORG|6,7 ORG

Then Intel changed the Pentium OverDrive , and the final version had a write - BACK cache .
1,2 ORG
1,2 ORG

When installed in a Gateway system , the chip ran slower than slow , maybe about as fast as an IBM AT , and bus - mastering devices like NICs and SCSI cards refused to work .
4,5 ORG|20,21 ORG
4,5 ORG|20,21 ORG

So the lawyers sued Gateway , and the settlement approved by the judge consisted of megabucks for the lawyers and coupons to owners of Gateway 486 computers .
2,3 PER|4,5 ORG|12,13 PER|18,19 PER|22,23 PER|24,25 ORG|3,4 Justice:Sue|3,13 Adjudicator|3,5 Defendant|2,4 r_Plaintiff
2,3 PER|4,5 ORG|12,13 PER|18,19 PER|22,23 PER|24,25 ORG|3,4 Justice:Sue|3,13 Adjudicator|3,5 Defendant|2,4 r_Plaintiff

The coupon was good for $ 50 off on the purchase of a Pentium OverDrive processor from Gateway , at its usual inflated prices !!!
17,18 ORG
17,18 ORG

So , let ' s see .
4,5 PER
4,5 PER

What does a discount coupon for a processor I can ' t use in my system do for me ?
8,9 PER|14,15 PER|18,19 PER
8,9 PER|14,15 PER|18,19 PER

I wonder how many people gleefully cashed in their coupons and bought Pentium OverDrives from Gateway .
0,1 PER|4,5 PER|8,9 PER|15,16 ORG
0,1 PER|4,5 PER|8,9 PER|15,16 ORG

Intel eventually compensated by making available an " interposer ", a little socketed thingie installed between the Pentium OverDrive and the ZIF socket .
0,1 ORG
0,1 ORG

The sole purpose of the interposer was to raise a signal on the CPU to force its cache to operate in the write - thru mode which was compatible with most ZIF Socket 3 486 motherboards .



Needless to say , this was the least successful " OverDrive " CPU ever done by Intel .
16,17 ORG
16,17 ORG

The 486 - DX4 OverDrive was OK , as were several Socket 5 Pentium OverDrives and the Socket 8 Pentium Pro OverDrive .



Finally Intel gave up on OverDrives ... Ben Myers
1,2 ORG|7,9 PER
1,2 ORG|7,9 PER

Nascar12
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

Sun , 27 Feb 2005 22 : 45 : 13 - 0500

Re : [ TAN ] Parole
5,6 Justice:Release-Parole
5,6 Justice:Release-Parole

Getting out on parole is usually a reward for good behavior while serving time .
3,4 Justice:Release-Parole
3,4 Justice:Release-Parole

So you ' re basically free , with the expectation that you will not leave the state ( assuming you ' ve been jailed by the state gov ' t ) and you have to check in with your parole officer on a regular basis ( I think they give you a schedule ).
1,2 PER|11,12 PER|16,17 GPE|19,20 PER|27,30 GPE|32,33 PER|38,39 PER|40,41 PER|46,47 PER|48,49 PER|50,51 PER|14,15 Movement:Transport|14,17 Origin|1,15 r_Artifact|23,24 Justice:Arrest-Jail|23,28 Agent|23,29 Agent|23,30 Agent|19,24 r_Person|39,40 Justice:Release-Parole|38,40 r_Person

I * believe * you are also expected to get a job , housing , etc .
0,1 PER|4,5 PER
0,1 PER|4,5 PER

and report this also .



In some cases you may be referred to a specific ' halfway ' house for reintroduction into society , and provided with a simple job .

5,6 PER|8,10 GPE

Re : [ TAN ] Parole
5,6 Justice:Release-Parole
5,6 Justice:Release-Parole

[...]



Indeed , New York ' s statute says , " Discretionary release on parole shall not be granted merely as a reward for good conduct or efficient performance of duties while confined but after considering if there is a reasonable probability that , if such inmate is released , he will live and remain at liberty without violating the law , and that his release is not incompatible with the welfare of society and will not so deprecate the seriousness of his crime as to undermine respect for law ."
2,4 GPE|45,46 PER|49,50 PER|63,64 PER|81,82 PER|11,12 Justice:Release-Parole|11,46 Person|13,14 Justice:Release-Parole|13,46 Person|47,48 Justice:Release-Parole|45,48 r_Person|64,65 Justice:Release-Parole|63,65 r_Person
2,4 GPE|45,46 PER|49,50 PER|63,64 PER|81,82 PER|11,12 Justice:Release-Parole|11,46 Person|13,14 Justice:Release-Parole|13,46 Person|47,48 Justice:Release-Parole|45,48 r_Person|64,65 Justice:Release-Parole|63,65 r_Person

N . Y . Executive Law 259 - i ( 2 )( c )( A ).
0,3 GPE
0,3 GPE

( Instead , there are ways of getting your parole eligibility date moved up for good behavior , or of creating strong presumptions in favor of parole release .)

Re : U . S . provoked Japan ?
2,6 GPE|7,8 GPE
2,6 GPE|7,8 GPE

Here ' s something I wrote as part of a larger article , some while ago :
4,5 PER
4,5 PER

Wasn ' t Japan just defending herself when she attacked the US ?
3,4 GPE|6,7 GPE|8,9 GPE|11,12 GPE|9,10 Conflict:Attack|8,10 r_Attacker
3,4 GPE|6,7 GPE|8,9 GPE|11,12 GPE|9,10 Conflict:Attack|8,10 r_Attacker

This line of reasoning seems to derive from arguments that Japan was being " driven into a corner " by sanctions , and had no choice but to attack the US .
10,11 GPE|30,31 GPE|28,29 Conflict:Attack|10,29 r_Attacker
10,11 GPE|30,31 GPE|28,29 Conflict:Attack|10,29 r_Attacker

Meiji Japan was driven to emulate what it thought the West was doing in every facet of society .
0,2 GPE|7,8 GPE|10,11 GPE
0,2 GPE|7,8 GPE|10,11 GPE

They had observed , for example , that the West was able to carve up China into " Spheres of Influence ", and was able to do from great distances , while they , the Japanese , had had limited success in their previous attempts to dominate the Korean peninsula , much less China .
0,1 GPE|9,10 GPE|15,16 GPE|32,33 GPE|35,36 GPE|42,43 GPE|48,50 GPE|53,54 GPE
0,1 GPE|9,10 GPE|15,16 GPE|32,33 GPE|35,36 GPE|42,43 GPE|48,50 GPE|53,54 GPE

As part of the catch - up effort , she whole - heartedly entered into the Imperialist game in Asia , being treated as an equal ( relative to her power ) by the other powers .
9,10 GPE|19,20 GPE|25,26 GPE|29,30 GPE|35,36 GPE
9,10 GPE|19,20 GPE|25,26 GPE|29,30 GPE|35,36 GPE

However , after World War I , Japan failed to recognize a fundamental shift in the attitudes of her former Imperial partners ; they began a long , slow process of disengaging themselves from their former Imperial areas , from their colonies , in addition to outright stopping all expansions .
7,8 GPE|18,19 GPE|21,22 GPE|23,24 GPE|32,33 GPE|34,35 GPE|37,38 LOC|40,41 GPE|41,42 LOC|4,5 Conflict:Attack
7,8 GPE|18,19 GPE|21,22 GPE|23,24 GPE|32,33 GPE|34,35 GPE|37,38 LOC|40,41 GPE|41,42 LOC|4,5 Conflict:Attack

Japan chose to read this as a sign that the West had lost its power and resolve , and that Japan was the rightful heir to Imperial mantle in Asia .
0,1 GPE|10,11 GPE|13,14 GPE|20,21 GPE|24,25 GPE|29,30 GPE
0,1 GPE|10,11 GPE|13,14 GPE|20,21 GPE|24,25 GPE|29,30 GPE

With the deaths of many of the idealistic leaders who had led Japan ' s rise to international prominence , and the refusal of the US to intervene in Asian affairs , in addition to the Bolshevik revolution and the stripping of possessions from Germany , Britain found herself alone in dealing with an increasingly aggressive Japan in the area .
4,5 PER|8,9 PER|9,10 PER|12,13 GPE|25,26 GPE|29,30 GPE|36,37 PER|42,43 LOC|44,45 GPE|46,47 GPE|48,49 GPE|56,57 GPE|59,60 LOC|2,3 Life:Die|2,5 Victim|37,38 Conflict:Attack|36,38 r_Attacker|40,41 Justice:Fine|40,45 Entity
4,5 PER|8,9 PER|9,10 PER|12,13 GPE|25,26 GPE|29,30 GPE|36,37 PER|42,43 LOC|44,45 GPE|46,47 GPE|48,49 GPE|56,57 GPE|59,60 LOC|2,3 Life:Die|2,5 Victim|37,38 Conflict:Attack|36,38 r_Attacker|40,41 Justice:Fine|40,45 Entity

Having a keen grasp of the obvious , she began a policy of acceding to Japanese hegemony in the area .
8,9 GPE|15,16 GPE|19,20 LOC
8,9 GPE|15,16 GPE|19,20 LOC

Japan continued a policy of acquiring territory for some grand , illusive scheme of a " Greater Asia ", subordinate and grateful to Japan .
0,1 GPE|6,7 LOC|16,18 LOC|23,24 GPE
0,1 GPE|6,7 LOC|16,18 LOC|23,24 GPE

The reality of this was that only a single possession , Manchuria , was profitable to the Japanese , and the rest of the Empire turned out to be a drain .
9,10 LOC|11,12 LOC|17,18 GPE|21,22 LOC|24,25 GPE
9,10 LOC|11,12 LOC|17,18 GPE|21,22 LOC|24,25 GPE

This drain was greatly accelerated by Japan ' s invasion of China proper in 1936 .
6,7 GPE|11,12 GPE|9,10 Conflict:Attack|6,10 r_Attacker
6,7 GPE|11,12 GPE|9,10 Conflict:Attack|6,10 r_Attacker

It was a war that Japan assumed would be ended in " 3 to 6 months "; at the time of Pearl Harbor , it had been going on for 5 years , at the cost of over half a million Japanese lives .
5,6 GPE|21,23 FAC|41,42 GPE|42,43 PER|3,4 Conflict:Attack|3,6 Attacker|35,36 Life:Die|35,43 Victim
5,6 GPE|21,23 FAC|41,42 GPE|42,43 PER|3,4 Conflict:Attack|3,6 Attacker|35,36 Life:Die|35,43 Victim

The war put a tremendous strain on Japan ( and was in fact opposed by more radically NATIONALISTIC elements , as taking away from the development of Japan ' s other possessions , particularly in the areas of scrap metal and fuel .)
7,8 GPE|18,19 PER|27,28 GPE|31,32 LOC|1,2 Conflict:Attack|1,8 Attacker
7,8 GPE|18,19 PER|27,28 GPE|31,32 LOC|1,2 Conflict:Attack|1,8 Attacker

Domestic consumption fell , consumer goods became scarce , and the use of materiale for war purposes ate into Japan ' s domestic industry .
19,20 GPE|15,16 Conflict:Attack|15,20 Attacker
19,20 GPE|15,16 Conflict:Attack|15,20 Attacker

This cut further into her foreign reserves , exacerbating the economic impact of the war .
4,5 GPE|14,15 Conflict:Attack|4,15 r_Attacker
4,5 GPE|14,15 Conflict:Attack|4,15 r_Attacker

The war effort took on a life of its own , however , and common sense was subordinated to it .
1,2 Conflict:Attack
1,2 Conflict:Attack

Japan expanded into areas of China and Indochina which had no strategic value to her , but put her in a position to threaten British and Dutch possessions in the area ; possessions that both those Allied nations needed in order to continue their fight against Hitler .
0,1 GPE|3,4 LOC|5,6 GPE|7,8 GPE|8,9 LOC|14,15 GPE|18,19 GPE|24,25 GPE|26,27 GPE|27,28 LOC|30,31 LOC|32,33 LOC|33,34 LOC|36,37 GPE|37,38 GPE|43,44 GPE|46,47 PER|44,45 Conflict:Attack|43,45 r_Attacker
0,1 GPE|3,4 LOC|5,6 GPE|7,8 GPE|8,9 LOC|14,15 GPE|18,19 GPE|24,25 GPE|26,27 GPE|27,28 LOC|30,31 LOC|32,33 LOC|33,34 LOC|36,37 GPE|37,38 GPE|43,44 GPE|46,47 PER|44,45 Conflict:Attack|43,45 r_Attacker

At this point , the US stopped ignoring the Japanese threat , and imposed a series of escalating sanctions on Japan , cutting off her scrap metal , limitting and then cutting off her oil ( Japan imported most of both from the US .)
5,6 GPE|9,10 GPE|20,21 GPE|24,25 GPE|33,34 GPE|36,37 GPE|43,44 GPE
5,6 GPE|9,10 GPE|20,21 GPE|24,25 GPE|33,34 GPE|36,37 GPE|43,44 GPE

While Japanese officials realized that they had enough of each resource for Japan to do well IF THE WAR IN CHINA STOPPED , they were powerless over the military they were supposed to control .
1,2 GPE|2,3 PER|5,6 GPE|12,13 GPE|20,21 GPE|23,24 PER|28,29 ORG|29,30 PER|18,19 Conflict:Attack|12,19 r_Attacker|18,21 Place

An abortive attack on Soviet positions in Mongolia had placed Japan ' s focus firmly south , towards the possessions of the US ' future allies .
4,5 GPE|7,8 GPE|10,11 GPE|19,20 LOC|22,23 GPE|25,26 GPE|2,3 Conflict:Attack|2,11 Attacker|2,8 Place

For no reason anyone could articulate , Japan felt she had to continue the war in China .
3,4 PER|7,8 GPE|9,10 GPE|16,17 GPE|14,15 Conflict:Attack|9,15 r_Attacker|14,17 Place

Thus , for a " 3 to 6 month " operation in China in 1937 , Japan would embark on a war that would strip her of all the possessions and industries she had acquired in 70 years .

The 1860 Presidential Election
3,4 Personnel:Elect
3,4 Personnel:Elect

In 1860 there was a four - way race between the Republican Party with Abraham Lincold , the Democratic Party with Stephen Douglas , the Southern Democratic Party with John Breckenridge , and the Constitutional Union Party with John Bell .
11,13 ORG|14,16 PER|18,20 ORG|21,23 PER|25,28 ORG|29,31 PER|34,37 ORG|38,40 PER
11,13 ORG|14,16 PER|18,20 ORG|21,23 PER|25,28 ORG|29,31 PER|34,37 ORG|38,40 PER

Lincoln won a plurality with about 40 % of the vote .
0,1 PER|1,2 Personnel:Elect|0,2 r_Person
0,1 PER|1,2 Personnel:Elect|0,2 r_Person

WI it was only a two - way race between Lincoln and Douglas ?
10,11 PER|12,13 PER
10,11 PER|12,13 PER

I believe Douglas would have won .
0,1 PER|2,3 PER|5,6 Personnel:Elect
0,1 PER|2,3 PER|5,6 Personnel:Elect

This would have delayed secession and the Civil War .

8,9 Conflict:Attack

Re : The 1860 Presidential Election
5,6 Personnel:Elect
5,6 Personnel:Elect

machiave ...@ aol . com ( Machiavegli ) wrote in
6,7 PER
6,7 PER

" One feature of the result must not be omitted .



Many careless observers felt at the time that the success of Lincoln was due entirely to the fact of there having been three opposing candidates in the field ; or , in other words , to the dissensions in the Democratic party , which divided its vote between Breckinridge and Douglas .
2,3 PER|11,12 PER|24,25 PER|40,42 ORG|43,44 ORG|45,46 ORG|48,49 PER|50,51 PER
2,3 PER|11,12 PER|24,25 PER|40,42 ORG|43,44 ORG|45,46 ORG|48,49 PER|50,51 PER

What merely moral strength the Democratic party would have gained had it remained united , it is impossible to estimate .
5,7 ORG|11,12 ORG
5,7 ORG|11,12 ORG

Such a supposition can only be based on the absence of the extreme Southern doctrines concerning slavery .
13,14 LOC
13,14 LOC

Given the presence of those doctrines in the canvass , no hypothesis can furnish a result different from that which occurred .



In the contest upon the questions as they existed , the victory of Lincoln was certain .
13,14 PER
13,14 PER

If all the votes given to all the opposing candidates had been concentrated and cast for a ' fusion ticket ,' as was wholly or partly done in five States , the result would have been changed nowhere except in New Jersey , California , and Oregon ; Lincoln would still have received but 11 fewer , or 169 electoral votes -- majority of 35 in the entire electoral college ."
9,10 PER|29,30 GPE|37,38 GPE|40,42 GPE|43,44 GPE|46,47 GPE|48,49 PER|69,70 ORG
9,10 PER|29,30 GPE|37,38 GPE|40,42 GPE|43,44 GPE|46,47 GPE|48,49 PER|69,70 ORG

Abraham Lincoln , A History , Volume 2 by John George Nicolay and John Hay
9,12 PER|13,15 PER
9,12 PER|13,15 PER

See for a confirmation of the electoral arithmetic : the states where Lincoln got an abolute majority of the popular vote ( i . e ., all the free states except Oregon , California , and New Jersey ) were sufficient to bring him a majority in the Electoral College .
10,11 GPE|11,12 GPE|12,13 PER|29,30 GPE|31,32 GPE|33,34 GPE|36,38 GPE|43,44 PER|49,50 ORG|6,7 Personnel:Elect|6,44 Person|6,11 Place|6,50 Entity
10,11 GPE|11,12 GPE|12,13 PER|29,30 GPE|31,32 GPE|33,34 GPE|36,38 GPE|43,44 PER|49,50 ORG|6,7 Personnel:Elect|6,44 Person|6,11 Place|6,50 Entity

The reason that Lincoln could get an electoral majority with only forty percent of the popular vote was not that his opposition was divided but that he had far fewer " wasted " votes than his opponents -- in ten southern states he got no popular votes at all .
3,4 PER|20,21 PER|26,27 PER|35,36 PER|36,37 PER|41,42 GPE|42,43 PER|7,8 Personnel:Elect|3,8 r_Person
3,4 PER|20,21 PER|26,27 PER|35,36 PER|36,37 PER|41,42 GPE|42,43 PER|7,8 Personnel:Elect|3,8 r_Person

It can of course be argued that the candidate of a united anti - Lincoln opposition might have done better than all the OTL anti - Lincoln candidates combined , because the mere fact of the divided nature of Lincoln ' s opposition might have discouraged anti - Lincoln men and led to fewer of them voting than would otherwise be the case .
8,9 PER|14,15 PER|26,27 PER|27,28 PER|39,40 PER|42,43 PER|48,49 PER|49,50 PER|53,54 PER|55,56 PER
8,9 PER|14,15 PER|26,27 PER|27,28 PER|39,40 PER|42,43 PER|48,49 PER|49,50 PER|53,54 PER|55,56 PER

But given that turnout was quite high in 1860 , I doubt this .
10,11 PER
10,11 PER

One thing seems reasonably clear to me : if there was to be a united anti - Lincoln opposition , Douglas could not lead it .
6,7 PER|17,18 PER|20,21 PER
6,7 PER|17,18 PER|20,21 PER

He was hated too much in the South for his opposition to the admission of Kansas as a state under the pro - slavery Lecompton Constitution and for his interpretation of Dred Scott as still allowing territories to exclude slavery through unfriendly local legislation .
0,1 PER|7,8 LOC|9,10 PER|15,16 GPE|18,19 GPE|28,29 PER|36,37 LOC
0,1 PER|7,8 LOC|9,10 PER|15,16 GPE|18,19 GPE|28,29 PER|36,37 LOC

( See



for Douglas ' s defense of his position .)
1,2 PER|6,7 PER
1,2 PER|6,7 PER

He and Breckinridge and Bell would have to withdraw in favor of a compromise candidate -- former governor Horatio Seymour of New York was one proposal .
0,1 PER|2,3 PER|4,5 PER|14,15 PER|17,18 PER|18,20 PER|21,23 GPE
0,1 PER|2,3 PER|4,5 PER|14,15 PER|17,18 PER|18,20 PER|21,23 GPE

But I doubt that Seymour would have been able to do better than all the combined OTL anti - Lincoln candidates in such close states as Illinois and Indiana And his own state of New York was not really close enough for me to believe he could have taken that state from the Lincoln column .

17 Feb 2005 17 : 19 : 51 - 0800



There is one Carousel organization again
4,5 ORG
4,5 ORG

I just received the latest issue of Merry - Go - Roundup , the quarterly publication of the National Carousel Association .
0,1 PER|18,21 ORG
0,1 PER|18,21 ORG

In it was a blurb reporting that the American Carousel Society had recently disbanded .
8,11 ORG|13,14 Business:End-Org|8,14 r_Org|9,14 r_Org|10,14 r_Org
8,11 ORG|13,14 Business:End-Org|8,14 r_Org

Some of you may be wondering why there were two carousel organizations in the first place .
0,1 PER|2,3 PER|11,12 ORG
0,1 PER|2,3 PER|11,12 ORG

The National Carousel Association was founded in the early 1970 ' s by a group of art historians and collectors , including Frederick Fried , author of the 1964 book " A Pictorial History of The Carousel " that single - handedly gave the classic hand - carved wooden carousel the respect and appreciation it deserved .
1,4 ORG|14,15 PER|17,18 PER|19,20 PER|22,24 PER|25,26 PER|5,6 Business:Start-Org|1,6 r_Org|2,6 r_Org|3,6 r_Org|5,15 Agent
1,4 ORG|14,15 PER|17,18 PER|19,20 PER|22,24 PER|25,26 PER|5,6 Business:Start-Org|1,6 r_Org|5,15 Agent

Other founders included Charlotte Dinger , who was already a major collector of carousel artwork at the time .
1,2 PER|3,5 PER|6,7 PER|11,12 PER
1,2 PER|3,5 PER|6,7 PER|11,12 PER

The purpose of the NCA is " to promote conservation , appreciation , knowledge and enjoyment of the art of the classic wooden carousel and especially the preservation of complete wooden carousels ."
4,5 ORG
4,5 ORG

The organization attracted a wide range of members , including carousel enthusiasts , owners / operators , theme and amusement parks , museums , libraries , those in the entertainment / recreation industry , art collectors and even auction houses , among others .
1,2 ORG|7,8 PER|11,12 PER|13,14 PER|15,16 PER|20,21 ORG|22,23 ORG|24,25 ORG|26,27 PER|32,33 ORG|35,36 PER|39,40 ORG|42,43 PER
1,2 ORG|7,8 PER|11,12 PER|13,14 PER|15,16 PER|20,21 ORG|22,23 ORG|24,25 ORG|26,27 PER|32,33 ORG|35,36 PER|39,40 ORG|42,43 PER

It was the presence of these last two named groups that would eventually stir up controversy .
9,10 PER
9,10 PER

Thanks in large part to the NCA , the art of the carousel was receiving a lot of public attention and appreciation that it had not enjoyed before .
6,7 ORG
6,7 ORG

However , this new and brighter spotlight on these antique rides also had the unfortunate effect of enhancing the collectibility and monetary value of operational carousels .



They had become worth more money dead ( i . e .



in pieces ) than alive ( i . e .



functioning ).



As such , during the 1980 ' s many beautiful and unique wooden carousels would be broken up at the auction block , as owners rushed to cash in on the antique marketplace .
24,25 PER
24,25 PER

The liability insurance crisis further aggravated the situation , as amusement park operators sought to cut their losses , while at the same time liquidate underperforming carousels to raise capital for the purchase of newer and more profitable ( thrill ) rides .
11,12 ORG|12,13 PER|16,17 PER
11,12 ORG|12,13 PER|16,17 PER

Some collectors of carousel art and auction houses were accused of using their NCA affiliation to gain information about vintage carousels that they could target for breakup to their own personal profit , a practice certainly contrary to the stated goals of the organization .
1,2 PER|7,8 ORG|12,13 PER|13,14 ORG|22,23 PER|28,29 PER|43,44 ORG
1,2 PER|7,8 ORG|12,13 PER|13,14 ORG|22,23 PER|28,29 PER|43,44 ORG

The increasing rift between the " preservationists " and " collectors " would eventually boil over into an internal political struggle that caused many in the collectors faction of the NCA to walk out of the group , including founders such as Charlotte Dinger and others .
6,7 PER|10,11 PER|23,24 PER|26,27 PER|27,28 PER|30,31 ORG|36,37 ORG|39,40 PER|42,44 PER|45,46 PER
6,7 PER|10,11 PER|23,24 PER|26,27 PER|27,28 PER|30,31 ORG|36,37 ORG|39,40 PER|42,44 PER|45,46 PER

The preservationists would chose to remain with the NCA , including Fred Fried .
1,2 PER|8,9 ORG|11,13 PER
1,2 PER|8,9 ORG|11,13 PER

At this time in the late 1970 ' s , carousel artwork collector and printer Marge Swenson was the editor of the NCA ' s Merry - Go - Roundup publication .
12,13 PER|14,15 PER|15,17 PER|19,20 PER|22,23 ORG
12,13 PER|14,15 PER|15,17 PER|19,20 PER|22,23 ORG

The political struggle that occurred within the NCA resulted in two slates of officers being presented for approval to the membership , something that was not supposed to happen .
7,8 ORG|13,14 PER|20,21 PER
7,8 ORG|13,14 PER|20,21 PER

A thicker - than - usual issue of the Roundup would be filled with accusations from both factions in the group each accusing the other of improper behavior .
17,18 PER|20,21 ORG|21,22 PER|24,25 PER
17,18 PER|20,21 ORG|21,22 PER|24,25 PER

Swenson herself would also leave the NCA .
0,1 PER|1,2 PER|6,7 ORG|4,5 Personnel:End-Position|0,5 r_Person|4,7 Entity
0,1 PER|1,2 PER|6,7 ORG|4,5 Personnel:End-Position|0,5 r_Person|4,7 Entity

Not much later , she began publishing her own magazine called " Carousel Art ", which was essentially a scholarly photo album depicting different carvers and styles each month .
4,5 PER|7,8 PER|24,25 PER
4,5 PER|7,8 PER|24,25 PER

Meanwhile , those collectors who left the National Carousel Association banded together to form the American Carousel Society ( ACS ), whose stated aims of carousel preservation also recognized collectors as a positive asset towards that goal .
3,4 PER|4,5 PER|7,10 ORG|15,18 ORG|19,20 ORG|21,22 ORG|29,30 PER|13,14 Business:Start-Org|13,16 Org|13,17 Org|13,18 Org|3,14 r_Agent
3,4 PER|4,5 PER|7,10 ORG|15,18 ORG|19,20 ORG|21,22 ORG|29,30 PER|13,14 Business:Start-Org|13,18 Org|3,14 r_Agent

For the next couple of decades , the two carousel organizations would co - exist , each attracting its share of members .
10,11 ORG|16,17 ORG|18,19 ORG|21,22 PER
10,11 ORG|16,17 ORG|18,19 ORG|21,22 PER

Some would actually join both groups , and even attend both of their annual conventions .
0,1 PER|5,6 ORG|12,13 ORG
0,1 PER|5,6 ORG|12,13 ORG

During the mid - 1980 ' s Walter Louck would begin publishing " The Carousel Trader ", later renamed " The Carousel News & Trader ".
7,9 PER
7,9 PER

This monthly magazine would cover all angles and sides of the story of the carousel and be well received by all carousel enthusiasts .
22,23 PER
22,23 PER

About a decade later , Carousel Art would suddenly cease publication .



The NCA would continue to issue the Roundup to its members .
1,2 ORG|9,10 ORG|10,11 PER
1,2 ORG|9,10 ORG|10,11 PER

The mid to late 1990 ' s saw the passing of NCA founder Fred Fried , and also that of Charlotte Dinger , both who represented the two opposite points of view in the carousel preservation debate .
11,12 ORG|12,13 PER|13,15 PER|20,22 PER|23,24 PER|24,25 PER|9,10 Life:Die|9,14 Victim|9,15 Victim|18,19 Life:Die|18,21 Victim|18,22 Victim
11,12 ORG|12,13 PER|13,15 PER|20,22 PER|23,24 PER|24,25 PER|9,10 Life:Die|9,15 Victim|18,19 Life:Die|18,22 Victim

Coincidentally and amazingly , the art of building hand - carved carousels ( and even bandorgans ) has been revived , with firms such as Carousel Works and Carousel Magic again building the popular rides in classic design .
22,23 ORG|25,27 ORG|28,30 ORG
22,23 ORG|25,27 ORG|28,30 ORG

This development seems to have greatly alleviated the antique marketplace pressures that have doomed so many legacy wooden carousels over the past several decades .



The turn of the new millenium actually witnessesed a thaw in the relationship between the National Carousel Association and American Carousel Society , as newer and younger leadership took over from the founding generation .
15,18 ORG|19,22 ORG|27,28 PER|33,34 PER
15,18 ORG|19,22 ORG|27,28 PER|33,34 PER

The truth about this election is this : Florida and Ohio had to go for Bush in order for him to " win " the election .
8,9 GPE|10,11 GPE|15,16 PER|19,20 PER|25,26 Personnel:Elect|19,26 r_Person

2,3 PER
2,3 PER

The exit polls were not wrong .



Kerry was the clear winner , but victory was snatched from him .
0,1 PER|4,5 PER|11,12 PER|7,8 Personnel:Elect|0,8 r_Person
0,1 PER|4,5 PER|11,12 PER|7,8 Personnel:Elect|0,8 r_Person

Florida first .
0,1 GPE
0,1 GPE

The 200 , 000 + margin of victory for Bush made this state uncontestable .
9,10 PER|12,13 GPE
9,10 PER|12,13 GPE

Everybody assumes that even with some fraud , Kerry could never have made up the difference in a recount .
0,1 PER|8,9 PER
0,1 PER|8,9 PER

But Kerry actually won by about 750 , 000 votes .
1,2 PER
1,2 PER

The numbers were changed by a computer program ( in both electronic and scan - tron voting systems ) called " Kerry Lite .
21,22 PER
21,22 PER

"" Kerry Lite " of course is not actual name of the program .
1,2 PER
1,2 PER

The actual name is 11 - 5 - 18 - 18 etc .



For additional encryption , the numbers were jumbled but I ' m not sure in which order .
9,10 PER
9,10 PER

The numbers replace the letters of the alphabet .



For example , K is the eleventh letter of the alphabet .



So the if - then statement goes something like this : " if total true Kerry ) total true Bush , Bush x 1 . 04x (. 04 is a random number )( total true Kerry ), total true Bush ".
15,16 PER|19,20 PER|21,22 PER|35,36 PER|39,40 PER
15,16 PER|19,20 PER|21,22 PER|35,36 PER|39,40 PER

The second part of the equation takes the total number of votes cast and subtracts the new Bush total , subtracts the third party totals and leaves the rest for Kerry .
17,18 PER|23,24 ORG|30,31 PER
17,18 PER|23,24 ORG|30,31 PER

Sometimes the program would also reduce third party votes and award them to Bush .
7,8 ORG|13,14 PER
7,8 ORG|13,14 PER

And even where Bush legitimately won , he was still awarded additional votes .
3,4 PER|7,8 PER
3,4 PER|7,8 PER

The big Democratic counties ( Broward for example ) went to Kerry because it had to appear that everything was on the up and up .
2,3 ORG|3,4 GPE|5,6 GPE|11,12 PER
2,3 ORG|3,4 GPE|5,6 GPE|11,12 PER

It ' s interesting to see this unfold .



Does anybody wonder why the Republican counties were mostly counted after the Democratic counties ?
1,2 PER|5,6 ORG|6,7 GPE|12,13 ORG|13,14 GPE
1,2 PER|5,6 ORG|6,7 GPE|12,13 ORG|13,14 GPE

You should wonder , and also know that this was no accident .
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

The Bush team had to make up the votes as the night went on .
1,2 PER|2,3 PER
1,2 PER|2,3 PER

In Ohio , computer voting fraud , vote tossing and voter suppression were the main methods .
1,2 GPE
1,2 GPE

Vote tossing was simply the removal of Kerry votes and some third party votes .
7,8 PER|12,13 ORG
7,8 PER|12,13 ORG

In some areas , the Bush vs . Kerry votes were absurd .
2,3 LOC|5,6 PER|8,9 PER
2,3 LOC|5,6 PER|8,9 PER

Nine to one , eight to two .



Voter suppression took the form of making voters stand in four hour long lines .
0,1 PER|7,8 PER
0,1 PER|7,8 PER

This of course took place in Democratic areas .
6,7 ORG|7,8 LOC
6,7 ORG|7,8 LOC

The simplest thing to do was to have too few voting machines .



Sometimes that ' s all it takes .



People eventually lose patience and leave without casting a vote .
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

In other states such as New Mexico , Nevada , Iowa and New Hampshire , Kerry ' s leads evaporated very quickly once the polls were shut down .
2,3 GPE|5,7 GPE|8,9 GPE|10,11 GPE|12,14 GPE|15,16 PER
2,3 GPE|5,7 GPE|8,9 GPE|10,11 GPE|12,14 GPE|15,16 PER

Kerry only won New Hampshire , but barely .
0,1 PER|3,5 GPE
0,1 PER|3,5 GPE

Re : waiver of extradition means what
4,5 Justice:Extradite
4,5 Justice:Extradite

The waiver of extradition that she signed simply means that if she skips out and goes to another state , she can ' t contest the right of the original court to have her hauled back to its jurisdiction , and that the court won ' t have to initiate the time - consuming process of extraditing her .
5,6 PER|11,12 PER|18,19 GPE|20,21 PER|30,31 ORG|33,34 PER|37,38 ORG|38,39 GPE|43,44 ORG|57,58 PER|3,4 Justice:Extradite|3,6 Person|3,19 Origin|3,39 Destination|3,31 Agent|12,13 Movement:Transport|11,13 r_Artifact|12,19 Destination|12,39 Origin|34,36 Movement:Transport|33,35 r_Artifact|33,36 r_Artifact|34,44 Agent|35,44 Agent|34,39 Destination|35,39 Destination|18,35 r_Origin|18,36 r_Origin|56,57 Justice:Extradite|56,58 Person|18,57 r_Origin|38,57 r_Destination|43,57 r_Agent
5,6 PER|11,12 PER|18,19 GPE|20,21 PER|30,31 ORG|33,34 PER|37,38 ORG|38,39 GPE|43,44 ORG|57,58 PER|3,4 Justice:Extradite|3,6 Person|3,19 Origin|3,39 Destination|3,31 Agent|12,13 Movement:Transport|11,13 r_Artifact|12,19 Destination|12,39 Origin|34,36 Movement:Transport|33,36 r_Artifact|34,44 Agent|34,39 Destination|18,36 r_Origin|56,57 Justice:Extradite|56,58 Person|18,57 r_Origin|38,57 r_Destination|43,57 r_Agent

Instead , if the cops pick her up , she can be shipped back without delay .
4,5 PER|6,7 PER|9,10 PER

Enron & India
0,1 ORG|2,3 GPE
0,1 ORG|2,3 GPE

In India , Bechtel along with General Electric are the new owners of the notorious and currently defunct Enron power project .
1,2 GPE|3,4 ORG|6,8 ORG|11,12 ORG|18,19 ORG
1,2 GPE|3,4 ORG|6,8 ORG|11,12 ORG|18,19 ORG

The Enron contract , which legally binds the Government of the State of Maharashtra to pay Enron a sum of 30 billion dollars , was the largest contract ever signed in India .
1,2 ORG|8,9 GPE|11,12 GPE|13,14 GPE|16,17 ORG|31,32 GPE
1,2 ORG|8,9 GPE|11,12 GPE|13,14 GPE|16,17 ORG|31,32 GPE

Enron was not shy to boast about the millions of dollars it had spent to " educate " Indian politicians and bureaucrats .
0,1 ORG|11,12 ORG|18,19 GPE|19,20 PER|21,22 PER
0,1 ORG|11,12 ORG|18,19 GPE|19,20 PER|21,22 PER

The Enron contract in Maharashtra , which was India ' s first ' fast - track ' private power project , has come to be known as the most massive fraud in the country ' s history .
1,2 ORG|4,5 GPE|8,9 GPE|33,34 GPE
1,2 ORG|4,5 GPE|8,9 GPE|33,34 GPE

( Enron was another of the Republican Party ' s major campaign contributors ).
1,2 ORG|3,4 ORG|6,8 ORG|12,13 ORG
1,2 ORG|3,4 ORG|6,8 ORG|12,13 ORG

The electricity that Enron produced was so exorbitant that the government decided it was cheaper not to buy electricity and pay Enron the mandatory fixed charges specified in the contract .
3,4 ORG|10,11 GPE|21,22 ORG|20,21 Transaction:Transfer-Money|10,21 r_Giver|20,22 Recipient
3,4 ORG|10,11 GPE|21,22 ORG|20,21 Transaction:Transfer-Money|10,21 r_Giver|20,22 Recipient

This means that the government of one of the poorest countries in the world was paying Enron 220 million US dollars a year not to produce electricity !
4,5 GPE|6,7 GPE|10,11 GPE|13,14 LOC|16,17 ORG|19,20 GPE|15,16 Transaction:Transfer-Money|4,16 r_Giver|15,17 Recipient
4,5 GPE|6,7 GPE|10,11 GPE|13,14 LOC|16,17 ORG|19,20 GPE|15,16 Transaction:Transfer-Money|4,16 r_Giver|15,17 Recipient

Now that Enron has ceased to exist , Bechtel and GE are suing the Indian Government for 5 . 6 billion US dollars .
2,3 ORG|8,9 ORG|10,11 ORG|14,15 GPE|15,16 GPE|21,22 GPE|4,5 Business:End-Org|2,5 r_Org|12,13 Justice:Sue|12,16 Defendant|8,13 r_Plaintiff|10,13 r_Plaintiff
2,3 ORG|8,9 ORG|10,11 ORG|14,15 GPE|15,16 GPE|21,22 GPE|4,5 Business:End-Org|2,5 r_Org|12,13 Justice:Sue|12,16 Defendant|8,13 r_Plaintiff|10,13 r_Plaintiff

This is not even a minute fraction of the sum of money that they ( or Enron ) actually invested in the project .
13,14 ORG|16,17 ORG
13,14 ORG|16,17 ORG

Once more , it ' s a projection of profit they would have made had the project materialized .
10,11 ORG
10,11 ORG

zztop8970

0,1 PER

Fri , 05 Nov 2004 15 : 36 : 53 GMT



Re : Enron & India
2,3 ORG|4,5 GPE
2,3 ORG|4,5 GPE

For a slightly different perspective :



" Maharashtra officials say the cost of power supplied by Enron is nearly double the tariff charged by Indian power producers , and used it as an excuse to stop paying state debts to the plant . "
1,2 GPE|2,3 PER|10,11 ORG|18,19 GPE|20,21 ORG|31,32 GPE|35,36 FAC
1,2 GPE|2,3 PER|10,11 ORG|18,19 GPE|20,21 ORG|31,32 GPE|35,36 FAC

" Enron had signed a power purchase agreement with power utility MSEB eight years ago , under which a $ 3bn 2 , 182 Megawatt power plant was to be commissioned .
1,2 ORG|10,11 ORG|11,12 ORG|26,27 FAC
1,2 ORG|10,11 ORG|11,12 ORG|26,27 FAC

But the project ran into trouble nearly two years ago with the Indian authorities beginning to delay payments saying Enron ' s power tariff was too high ... Though Enron officials refuse to talk about the price they would be willing to sell their stake at , analysts say the US company is demanding about one billion dollars for its investments in India .
12,13 GPE|13,14 PER|19,20 ORG|29,30 ORG|30,31 PER|37,38 PER|43,44 PER|47,48 PER|50,51 GPE|51,52 ORG|59,60 ORG|62,63 GPE
12,13 GPE|13,14 PER|19,20 ORG|29,30 ORG|30,31 PER|37,38 PER|43,44 PER|47,48 PER|50,51 GPE|51,52 ORG|59,60 ORG|62,63 GPE

So far it has only got offers of about half that amount from Indian companies and financial institutions , but Enron is unwilling to sell its stake at a price lower than the cost .
2,3 ORG|13,14 GPE|14,15 ORG|17,18 ORG|20,21 ORG|25,26 ORG
2,3 ORG|13,14 GPE|14,15 ORG|17,18 ORG|20,21 ORG|25,26 ORG

In case no satisfactory offer comes from the Indian side , Enron will have little option but to go for international arbitration as their investments in the country were guaranteed by the Indian Government .
8,9 GPE|11,12 ORG|23,24 ORG|27,28 GPE|32,33 GPE|33,34 GPE
8,9 GPE|11,12 ORG|23,24 ORG|27,28 GPE|32,33 GPE|33,34 GPE

But arbitration proceedings can be a long and messy affair .



Analysts say both India and Enron have little to gain from a protracted legal battle .
0,1 PER|3,4 GPE|5,6 ORG
0,1 PER|3,4 GPE|5,6 ORG

The best way out could be a compromise by which Enron gets less than what it is demanding and more than what the Indians are presently offering .
10,11 ORG|15,16 ORG|23,24 GPE
10,11 ORG|15,16 ORG|23,24 GPE

IOW : No fraud , just a basic business dispute , in which the party reneging on its obligations is the gov ' t of Maharashtra .
8,9 ORG|14,15 GPE|17,18 GPE|21,24 GPE|25,26 GPE
8,9 ORG|14,15 GPE|17,18 GPE|21,24 GPE|25,26 GPE

The Maharashtra officials are either incompetent fools , or worse - malicious fraudsters who conned an international comapny into building a state - of - the - art power plant for them at a cost of billions of dollars , and then refused payment , knowing the company has no legal recourse except lengthy international arbitration , and will likely sell the plant to them for a fraction of its true value .
1,2 GPE|2,3 PER|6,7 PER|12,13 PER|13,14 PER|17,18 ORG|29,30 FAC|31,32 PER|47,48 ORG|62,63 FAC|64,65 PER|69,70 FAC|60,61 Transaction:Transfer-Ownership|60,63 Artifact|47,61 r_Seller|60,65 Buyer
1,2 GPE|2,3 PER|6,7 PER|12,13 PER|13,14 PER|17,18 ORG|29,30 FAC|31,32 PER|47,48 ORG|62,63 FAC|64,65 PER|69,70 FAC|60,61 Transaction:Transfer-Ownership|60,63 Artifact|47,61 r_Seller|60,65 Buyer

Within weeks after taking charge of a public company that had even managed to turn a slight profit , WITHOUT MAKING ANY IMPROVEMENTS WHATSOEVER IN THE WATER SYSTEM , Bechtel doubled and tripled water rates , charging the poor of the city $ 15 or more a month just to keep their water running ... in a city where families live on less than $ 60 per month .

Club Sports policies at schools ; specifically travel restrictions
0,1 ORG|4,5 ORG
0,1 ORG|4,5 ORG

Hello everyone -
1,2 PER
1,2 PER

I am attempting to learn more information about the policies of various athletic departments at schools , specifically with regards to ultimate teams .
0,1 PER|13,14 ORG|15,16 ORG|22,23 ORG
0,1 PER|13,14 ORG|15,16 ORG|22,23 ORG

At Northwestern , the Men ' s Ultimate team falls under the Club Sports department which falls into a dark , barely lit corner of the Athletic Department .
1,2 ORG|4,5 PER|8,9 ORG|14,15 ORG|15,16 ORG|27,28 ORG
1,2 ORG|4,5 PER|8,9 ORG|14,15 ORG|15,16 ORG|27,28 ORG

There are some restrictions on what we can and cannot do .
6,7 ORG
6,7 ORG

The one that I am most interested in comparing to similar policies at other schools concerns our ability to travel .
3,4 PER|14,15 ORG|16,17 ORG
3,4 PER|14,15 ORG|16,17 ORG

At Northwestern , we are allowed to either rent school vans for no charge or take our own vehicles to tournaments within 300 miles of Evanston , IL .
1,2 ORG|3,4 ORG|9,10 ORG|10,11 VEH|16,17 ORG|17,18 ORG|18,19 VEH|25,26 GPE|27,28 GPE
1,2 ORG|3,4 ORG|9,10 ORG|10,11 VEH|16,17 ORG|17,18 ORG|18,19 VEH|25,26 GPE|27,28 GPE

Also , we are allowed to fly , take a bus , or take Amtrak to any tournament we want , no matter how far away it is .
2,3 ORG|10,11 VEH|14,15 VEH|18,19 ORG
2,3 ORG|10,11 VEH|14,15 VEH|18,19 ORG

We are allowed to compete under the Northwestern name if we take any of these options .
0,1 ORG|7,8 ORG|10,11 ORG
0,1 ORG|7,8 ORG|10,11 ORG

However , it often occurs that we want to go to a tournament farther than 300 miles without flying .
6,7 ORG
6,7 ORG

( For example , Regionals is often slightly farther than 300 miles , yet a reasonable drive .)



If we choose to do so , it is understood that we are not officially competing under the Northwestern name - we are just a group of people playing ultimate at a tournament and not involving the university in any way .
1,2 ORG|11,12 ORG|18,19 ORG|21,22 ORG|25,26 ORG|27,28 PER|37,38 ORG
1,2 ORG|11,12 ORG|18,19 ORG|21,22 ORG|25,26 ORG|27,28 PER|37,38 ORG

Do any of you other college players face similar restrictions in your travel ?
1,2 PER|3,4 PER|5,6 ORG|6,7 PER|11,12 PER
1,2 PER|3,4 PER|5,6 ORG|6,7 PER|11,12 PER

What are your schools ' policies ?
2,3 PER|3,4 ORG
2,3 PER|3,4 ORG

I am interested in both the responses of players at public and private schools .
0,1 PER|8,9 PER|13,14 ORG
0,1 PER|8,9 PER|13,14 ORG

Feel free to email me if you do want to post to the forum .
4,5 PER|6,7 PER|3,4 Contact:Phone-Write|3,5 Entity|3,7 Entity

Re : S Corp Profit distribution and Bankrupcy .
2,4 ORG
2,4 ORG

Was the trustee informed of the transfer of the shares ?
2,3 PER
2,3 PER

Since you gave your uncle the shares prior to his discharge , the shares should have become assets available to the bankruptcy estate for the satisfaction of debts .
1,2 PER|3,4 PER|4,5 PER|9,10 PER|21,22 Business:Declare-Bankruptcy|9,22 r_Org
1,2 PER|3,4 PER|4,5 PER|9,10 PER|21,22 Business:Declare-Bankruptcy|9,22 r_Org

If the share transfer was reported to the trustee and the trustee did nothing about them , then you may be ok ; however , if you failed to inform the trustee , then your uncle may be liable for hiding assets , which would , at the minimum , invalidate his discharge .
8,9 PER|11,12 PER|18,19 PER|26,27 PER|31,32 PER|34,35 PER|35,36 PER|51,52 PER
8,9 PER|11,12 PER|18,19 PER|26,27 PER|31,32 PER|34,35 PER|35,36 PER|51,52 PER

Even if the transfer doesn ' t invalidate the whole discharge , the distribution might be subject to forfeiture to pay creditors ' claims if you failed to inform the trustee of the share transfer .
21,22 PER|25,26 PER|30,31 PER
21,22 PER|25,26 PER|30,31 PER

You need to speak to a bankruptcy attorney pronto ; this is a bankruptcy matter , not a tax matter .
0,1 PER|7,8 PER|6,7 Business:Declare-Bankruptcy|13,14 Business:Declare-Bankruptcy
0,1 PER|7,8 PER|6,7 Business:Declare-Bankruptcy|13,14 Business:Declare-Bankruptcy

2,4 ORG|7,8 Business:Declare-Bankruptcy

Yes , but according to the facts you first gave , he had not yet received the bankruptcy discharge when you gave him the shares .
7,8 PER|11,12 PER|20,21 PER|22,23 PER|17,18 Business:Declare-Bankruptcy
7,8 PER|11,12 PER|20,21 PER|22,23 PER|17,18 Business:Declare-Bankruptcy

I believe you had said that you gave him the shares in February 2004 but that the discharge didn ' t come until June of 2004 .
0,1 PER|2,3 PER|6,7 PER|8,9 PER|7,8 Transaction:Transfer-Ownership|7,9 Beneficiary|0,8 r_Seller
0,1 PER|2,3 PER|6,7 PER|8,9 PER|7,8 Transaction:Transfer-Ownership|7,9 Beneficiary|0,8 r_Seller

That means that he received the shares while he was still in bankruptcy , which means that the shares were potentially assets that the trustee could use to pay off creditors .
3,4 PER|8,9 PER|24,25 PER|30,31 PER|12,13 Business:Declare-Bankruptcy|8,13 r_Org
3,4 PER|8,9 PER|24,25 PER|30,31 PER|12,13 Business:Declare-Bankruptcy|8,13 r_Org

A bankruptcy case doesn ' t close until you get the discharge order , and until then everything that the debtor receives is fair game for the trustee .
8,9 PER|20,21 PER|27,28 PER|1,2 Business:Declare-Bankruptcy
8,9 PER|20,21 PER|27,28 PER|1,2 Business:Declare-Bankruptcy

If the trustee was informed of the shares and did nothing about it , you are more likely than not ok , but if the trustee wasn ' t informed of the fact directly , then you may be in trouble .
2,3 PER|14,15 PER|25,26 PER|36,37 PER
2,3 PER|14,15 PER|25,26 PER|36,37 PER

If , however , your uncle received the shares after he obtained an order of discharge from the bankruptcy court , then as a general matter the creditors cannot go after the shares , unless they can prove that there was collusion between you and your uncle to hide his assets from them ( e . g ., by putting his assets in the corporation ' s name and then waiting until after the bankruptcy to transfer the shares to him ).

Let ' s see ...
2,3 PER
2,3 PER

There two main qualities to be desired in a Commander - in - Chief , Generalship and Leadership .
9,14 PER
9,14 PER

Because in the United States the Commander - in - Chief is a purely political post , generalship is usually undertaken by the generals proper under the Commander - in - Chief , provided it is understood that the Commander - in - Chief is ultimately responsible and accountable for the outcomes of his general ' s generalship .
3,5 GPE|6,11 PER|23,24 PER|27,32 PER|39,44 PER|53,54 PER|54,55 PER
3,5 GPE|6,11 PER|23,24 PER|27,32 PER|39,44 PER|53,54 PER|54,55 PER

Generalship involves the technical skills of intelligence gathering , strategic and tactical planning , and the communication of orders .



Leadership can be less rigidly defined and is concerned less with coordination than motivation and how a commander seeks to inspire his men to fight harder and endure worse privations in order to beat the enemy .
17,18 PER|21,22 PER|22,23 PER|35,36 PER|24,25 Conflict:Attack|22,25 r_Attacker

Well , those of you who still believe the myth of the liberal media should consider this : MSNBC , an obscure cable channel , has fired Phil Donahue , the host of its highest - rated show .
2,3 PER|4,5 PER|5,6 PER|13,14 ORG|18,19 ORG|23,24 ORG|27,29 PER|31,32 PER|33,34 ORG|26,27 Personnel:End-Position|26,28 Person|26,29 Person
2,3 PER|4,5 PER|5,6 PER|13,14 ORG|18,19 ORG|23,24 ORG|27,29 PER|31,32 PER|33,34 ORG|26,27 Personnel:End-Position|26,29 Person

A memo from inside NBC , reported on the Web site allyourtv . com , and today in " The Washington Post ," shows NBC big wigs feared that the liberal Mr . Donahue represented in the words of the NBC memo -- quote -- " a difficult public face for NBC at a time of war , while our competitors are waving the flag at every opportunity because he seems to delight in presenting guests who are anti - war , anti - Bush and skeptical of the administration ' s motives ."

0,2 ORG|6,7 ORG|14,15 PER|21,22 ORG|7,8 Justice:Charge-Indict|6,8 r_Defendant|7,22 Prosecutor

The amount in question : $ 37 million .

Back in the day ( 2000 - 2003 or so ) some of the hottest non - homebuilding stocks were the gaming equipment manufacturers , who rode a wave of heavy reinvestment in casinos to produce huge profits .
23,24 ORG|25,26 ORG|33,34 ORG
23,24 ORG|25,26 ORG|33,34 ORG

Now , all that reinvestment has paid off , and , along with a good dose of consolidation , made the industry moderately hot again .
21,22 ORG
21,22 ORG

Like every boom , whether merited or not , the big companies have big moves in the early stage , but it doesn ' t get attention or turn into a mania until we see a frenetic IPO or two .
11,12 ORG|33,34 PER
11,12 ORG|33,34 PER

You know where this is going : Las Vegas Sands kicked off its first trading day with a 60 % gain after a last - minute increase in offering price to $ 29 a share , outside the $ 24 -$ 26 range bandied about after they dropped their first $ 20 -$ 22 estimate .
0,1 PER|7,10 ORG|12,13 ORG|46,47 ORG|48,49 ORG
0,1 PER|7,10 ORG|12,13 ORG|46,47 ORG|48,49 ORG

Read this report on the U . S .- Russia Technology Symposium .
5,8 GPE|9,10 GPE
5,8 GPE|9,10 GPE

It ' s a great summary of the paradoxes of the Russian economy : They have a huge untapped supply of valuable IT labor , but their IT exports are only a tenth of their military exports ( and only a thirtieth of India ' s IT exports ).
11,12 GPE|14,15 GPE|26,27 GPE|34,35 GPE|43,44 GPE
11,12 GPE|14,15 GPE|26,27 GPE|34,35 GPE|43,44 GPE

0,1 GPE|8,9 PER|11,12 PER

Hand in hand with any consideration of the redistricting process , we shoul give some thought to the structural relationship between the state House and Senate .
11,12 PER|22,23 GPE|23,24 ORG|25,26 ORG
11,12 PER|22,23 GPE|23,24 ORG|25,26 ORG

Currently , each House member represents approximately 75 , 000 Virginians , while each Senator represents appoximately 187 , 500 .
3,4 ORG|4,5 PER|10,11 PER|14,15 PER|17,20 PER
3,4 ORG|4,5 PER|10,11 PER|14,15 PER|17,20 PER

Often as not , there is no rational commonality between the two .
11,12 PER
11,12 PER

Some senators represent people pools that are in turn fractured into five or six House districts .
1,2 PER|3,4 PER|4,5 PER|5,6 PER|14,15 ORG|15,16 LOC
1,2 PER|3,4 PER|4,5 PER|5,6 PER|14,15 ORG|15,16 LOC

I believe this accounts , in large part , for the dysfunction that characterizes our state government now .
0,1 PER|14,15 GPE|15,16 GPE|16,17 GPE
0,1 PER|14,15 GPE|15,16 GPE|16,17 GPE

Former Governor Gerald Baliles , in this same vein , has advocated a realignment of the two houses in a way that serves commonalities .
1,2 PER|2,4 PER|17,18 PER|0,1 Personnel:End-Position|0,2 Person
1,2 PER|2,4 PER|17,18 PER|0,1 Personnel:End-Position|0,2 Person

He has suggested that we either increase membership in the Senate to 50 , or decrease House membership to 80 , producing a scenario wherein 1 Senator would represent a block of people who are represented by exactly 2 Delegates .
0,1 PER|4,5 GPE|7,8 PER|10,11 ORG|12,13 PER|16,17 ORG|17,18 PER|19,20 PER|26,27 PER|30,31 PER|33,34 PER|39,40 PER
0,1 PER|4,5 GPE|7,8 PER|10,11 ORG|12,13 PER|16,17 ORG|17,18 PER|19,20 PER|26,27 PER|30,31 PER|33,34 PER|39,40 PER

He thinks -- and I think he is right -- that this arrangement would foster a closer working relationship between the Senate and the House .
0,1 PER|4,5 PER|6,7 PER|21,22 ORG|24,25 ORG
0,1 PER|4,5 PER|6,7 PER|21,22 ORG|24,25 ORG

You certainly wouldn ' t have these dysfunctional groupings we now have , where 1 Senator often represents a population divided among half a dozen Delegates of two parties -- three , if you count independents .
0,1 PER|8,9 PER|9,10 GPE|13,14 PER|15,16 PER|19,20 PER|25,26 PER|28,29 ORG|30,31 ORG|33,34 PER|35,36 PER
0,1 PER|8,9 PER|9,10 GPE|13,14 PER|15,16 PER|19,20 PER|25,26 PER|28,29 ORG|30,31 ORG|33,34 PER|35,36 PER

2004 - 12 - 03T19 : 59 : 00



Here ' s an incredible story about an unsung hero until now .
9,10 PER
9,10 PER

From BBC News : A retired Italian doctor has revealed for the first time how he invented a fictitious disease which fooled the Nazis during World War II .
1,3 ORG|6,7 GPE|7,8 PER|15,16 PER|23,24 PER
1,3 ORG|6,7 GPE|7,8 PER|15,16 PER|23,24 PER

The trick of prescribing Jews with a mysterious illness terrified the Nazis and saved 45 Roman Jews .
4,5 PER|11,12 PER|15,16 GPE|16,17 PER
4,5 PER|11,12 PER|15,16 GPE|16,17 PER

Dr Vittorio Sacerdoti has told his remarkable tale on the 60th anniversary of liberation of Rome .
1,3 PER|5,6 PER|15,16 GPE
1,3 PER|5,6 PER|15,16 GPE

Just 28 years old at the time , he used courage and ingenuity to save 45 people from certain death .
8,9 PER|16,17 PER
8,9 PER|16,17 PER

As other Jews were being rounded up , Dr Sacerdoti admitted anyone who could reach the hospital as patients - and diagnosed them with a dangerous disease .
2,3 PER|9,10 PER|11,12 PER|12,13 PER|16,17 FAC|18,19 PER|22,23 PER
2,3 PER|9,10 PER|11,12 PER|12,13 PER|16,17 FAC|18,19 PER|22,23 PER

" We would write on their medical forms that the patient was suffering from K Syndrome ," he said .
1,2 PER|5,6 PER|10,11 PER|17,18 PER
1,2 PER|5,6 PER|10,11 PER|17,18 PER

" We called it K after the German commander Kesserling - the Nazis thought it was cancer or tuberculosis , and they fled like rabbits ."
1,2 PER|7,8 GPE|8,9 PER|9,10 PER|12,13 PER|21,22 PER
1,2 PER|7,8 GPE|8,9 PER|9,10 PER|12,13 PER|21,22 PER

K Syndrome saved his cousin , Luciana Sacerdoti , who was just 10 years old .
3,4 PER|4,5 PER|6,8 PER|9,10 PER
3,4 PER|4,5 PER|6,8 PER|9,10 PER

" The day the Nazis came to the hospital , someone came to our room and said : ' You have to cough , you have to cough a lot because they are afraid of the coughing , they don ' t want to catch an awful disease and they won ' t enter '."
4,5 PER|8,9 FAC|10,11 PER|13,14 PER|14,15 FAC|19,20 PER|24,25 PER|31,32 PER|38,39 PER|49,50 PER|5,6 Contact:Meet|5,9 Place|4,6 r_Entity
4,5 PER|8,9 FAC|10,11 PER|13,14 PER|14,15 FAC|19,20 PER|24,25 PER|31,32 PER|38,39 PER|49,50 PER|5,6 Contact:Meet|5,9 Place|4,6 r_Entity

The market didn ' t have an intelligent way to react to this news ( except to send NASDAQ , which I ' ve been cheerleading for a while , up 10 . 46 % in sympathy ), but the New York Stock Exchange may actually convert to a for - profit entity .
18,19 ORG|20,21 ORG|21,22 PER|40,44 ORG|52,53 ORG

0,1 ORG
0,1 ORG

Not to name names or anything .



The exchange needs this : it ' s ossified , the real owners -- holders of exchange seats -- have seen their investment lose 40 % in a year ( though they can still earn an income from it to offset the losses ), and the NASDAQ has undercut their traditional dominance among growth companies - turned - blue chips .

Market over reaction ?



Hard to say .



Both companies have pricey stocks and those valuations are based on optimistic expectations of future growth .
1,2 ORG
1,2 ORG

Yesterday ' s news led many to question their growth assumptions for these companies .
5,6 PER|8,9 PER|13,14 ORG

Today I want to talk a bit about Starbucks .
1,2 PER|8,9 ORG
1,2 PER|8,9 ORG

I think I have to start by acknowledging that the stock is still pricey even after its drop yesterday .
0,1 PER|2,3 PER
0,1 PER|2,3 PER

However , my organizational indicators analysis reveals a very low level of business risk .
2,3 PER
2,3 PER

This may partially justify a higher P / E ratio .



A couple weeks ago , I observed that Wal - Mart had offsetting strong and weak organizational indicators .
5,6 PER|8,11 ORG
5,6 PER|8,11 ORG

Starbucks , on the other hand , has uniformly strong organizational indicators .
0,1 ORG
0,1 ORG

Starbucks scores as best in its industry on six of seven organizational indicators .
0,1 ORG|5,6 ORG
0,1 ORG|5,6 ORG

Not surprising are it s strong scores in the employee relations and stakeholder actions indicators .
3,4 ORG|9,10 PER|12,13 PER
3,4 ORG|9,10 PER|12,13 PER

It s weakest score is in the external reporting indicator .
0,1 ORG
0,1 ORG

In the past , several observers have raised concerns about aggressive accounting at Starbucks but my analysis does not indicate any systematic current issues .
5,6 PER|13,14 ORG|15,16 PER
5,6 PER|13,14 ORG|15,16 PER

The weak score is primarily the result of Starbucks current strategy of increasing equity ownership of several foreign subsidiaries .
8,9 ORG|18,19 ORG
8,9 ORG|18,19 ORG

This is a strategic shift that has short - term costs and adds some uncertainty to the financial statements .



Beyond the strong Organizational Indicator analysis , several additional factors favor Starbucks ability to continue to grow revenues .
11,12 ORG
11,12 ORG

1 .



Starbucks has little debt .
0,1 ORG
0,1 ORG

Starbucks is not currently financing it s growth with debt .
0,1 ORG|5,6 ORG
0,1 ORG|5,6 ORG

Considering it s growth , this is amazing .
1,2 ORG
1,2 ORG

It also means that Starbucks has a large amount of flexibility in how it finances future growth .
4,5 ORG|13,14 ORG
4,5 ORG|13,14 ORG

The company can assume much more debt without negatively affecting it s risk profile because ...
1,2 ORG|10,11 ORG
1,2 ORG|10,11 ORG

2 .



Starbucks has a healthy cashflow and current cash position .
0,1 ORG
0,1 ORG

This allows the company to grow without debt .
3,4 ORG
3,4 ORG

You could argue that Starbucks has too much cash and should do more to pass it on to shareholders .
0,1 PER|4,5 ORG|18,19 PER
0,1 PER|4,5 ORG|18,19 PER

This option is another way that Starbucks has retained it s flexibility for the future .
6,7 ORG|9,10 ORG
6,7 ORG|9,10 ORG

3 .



Starbucks is the primary owner of it s stores and limits franchising .
0,1 ORG|4,5 ORG|6,7 ORG|8,9 FAC
0,1 ORG|4,5 ORG|6,7 ORG|8,9 FAC

While Starbucks does partner ( airlines , airports , Barnes & N oble ), most of it s stores are company owned .
1,2 ORG|5,6 ORG|7,8 FAC|9,12 ORG|14,15 FAC|16,17 ORG|18,19 FAC|20,21 ORG
1,2 ORG|5,6 ORG|7,8 FAC|9,12 ORG|14,15 FAC|16,17 ORG|18,19 FAC|20,21 ORG

From a managerial perspective this greatly simplifies cost structures , product changes , and quality control .



Taken together all of these factors paint a picture of a company with a very strong future .
11,12 ORG
11,12 ORG

I cannot say if these factors justify the current share price but I would say that they justify a higher P / E ratio than the industry norm .
0,1 PER|12,13 PER
0,1 PER|12,13 PER

Risk is lower .

0,1 PER|6,7 ORG|11,12 GPE|12,13 PER|22,23 PER|29,30 PER|32,33 PER|39,40 PER
0,1 PER|6,7 ORG|11,12 GPE|12,13 PER|22,23 PER|29,30 PER|32,33 PER|39,40 PER

15,16 ORG|19,20 PER
15,16 ORG|19,20 PER

7,8 PER
7,8 PER

Clearly , they were expecting lots more damage .
2,3 PER
2,3 PER

These insider sales were certainly stupid , and probably criminal ( though the legal proof may be hard to come by ) but the solution is easy enough : They need to buy stock from the company itself , at some premium to the prices at which they sold -- they ' ll have the same stake as before , the shareholders would have gotten their money back ( since the premium goes to the company , which is owned by the shareholders ), and there ' s no need to disrupt their business by taking the matter to court .
29,30 PER|36,37 ORG|37,38 ORG|50,51 PER|61,62 PER|65,66 PER|75,76 ORG|77,78 ORG|82,83 PER|92,93 PER|99,100 ORG|32,33 Transaction:Transfer-Ownership|32,37 Seller|29,33 r_Buyer

Or , if you want to do things the SEC ' s way , you could 1 ) Hire a bunch of lawyers with the company ' s ( shareholders ') money , 2 ) Hire a legion of PR firms to explain away that frivolous spending , 3 ) Hire a new accountant to magically turn that spending into an investment amortizable over twenty years , and 4 ) Settle out - of - court by having the execs give the SEC some pittance ( for which they ' ll likely be compensated by the company ) and a statement that " We neither admit nor deny that we did what you claim , but we ' ll never do it again ."

2005 - 02 - 04T13 : 37 : 00



According to the usually reliable CNN / Money , the " Twin Deficits " will continue to grow .
5,6 ORG
5,6 ORG

Interesting terminology ...



I believe they ' re referring to the budget deficit and ... the capital surplus ?
0,1 PER|2,3 ORG
0,1 PER|2,3 ORG

When analyzing trade deficits , it ' s important to realize that the amount by which imports exceed exports is also equal to the net amount foreign investors have bet on the US .
27,28 PER|32,33 GPE
27,28 PER|32,33 GPE

So the trade deficit is due to a confluence of the pressures from US consumers ( who control about 20 % of global GDP ) and everybody else ( excluding the non - consumption share of US GDP , that would amount to around 75 % of global GDP ).
13,14 GPE|14,15 PER|16,17 PER|26,27 PER|36,37 GPE
13,14 GPE|14,15 PER|16,17 PER|26,27 PER|36,37 GPE

Which of those is -- probably -- going to be a more important number ?



Even if we are consumers bent on gorging ourselves with imported goods , the largest pressure on the deficit is that we ' re simply a better place for investment -- higher returns on capital in developing countries are more than mitigated by the higher political risks they face .
2,3 GPE|4,5 GPE|8,9 GPE|21,22 GPE|27,28 GPE|37,38 GPE|47,48 GPE
2,3 GPE|4,5 GPE|8,9 GPE|21,22 GPE|27,28 GPE|37,38 GPE|47,48 GPE

And what about that other deficit ?



It , of course , is the ominous sum that we fund without taxes , but by borrowing funds .
10,11 GPE
10,11 GPE

And about half of those borrowings end up with the major banks in Asia .
11,12 ORG|13,14 GPE
11,12 ORG|13,14 GPE

So , not to be a heretic , but 1 ) We ' re issuing them at relatively low interest rates , 2 ) Inflation is bound to pick up eventually , and so 3 ) Wouldn ' t you rather have our deficits made up by economically nonsensical purchases by non - US investors , rather than raising taxes in America ?
11,12 GPE|39,40 PER|42,43 GPE|53,54 GPE|54,55 PER|61,62 GPE
11,12 GPE|39,40 PER|42,43 GPE|53,54 GPE|54,55 PER|61,62 GPE

It ' s a question of who will pay for the same spending , and all else being equal I ' d be happy for Asian central banks to pick up the tab .
6,7 PER|19,20 PER|25,26 GPE|27,28 ORG
6,7 PER|19,20 PER|25,26 GPE|27,28 ORG

The Twin Deficits are a reality , but they aren ' t exactly a terrifying one .



Scott
0,1 PER
0,1 PER

What ' s notable in this debate , however , is that according to MSN Moneycentral , tobacco executives are attacking the tax by noting that " While North Carolina ' s excise tax is only 5 cents , the total taxes given to North Carolina by smokers adds up to more than 61 cents per pack ."
14,16 ORG|18,19 PER|28,30 GPE|44,46 GPE|47,48 PER|42,43 Transaction:Transfer-Money|42,48 Giver|42,45 Recipient|42,46 Recipient
14,16 ORG|18,19 PER|28,30 GPE|44,46 GPE|47,48 PER|42,43 Transaction:Transfer-Money|42,48 Giver|42,46 Recipient

7,8 ORG|14,15 GPE|8,9 Transaction:Transfer-Money|7,9 r_Giver|8,15 Recipient
7,8 ORG|14,15 GPE|8,9 Transaction:Transfer-Money|7,9 r_Giver|8,15 Recipient

But the point of these taxes is to align the price of a pack with the cost to society , and inasmuch as these penalties aren ' t assessed on a per - pack basis , they don ' t -- they ' re a lump - sum reflection of the taxes these companies ought to have paid before .
18,19 PER|53,54 ORG
18,19 PER|53,54 ORG

Interestingly , the policy of making cigarette buyers pay to compensate society for the costs they impose is a politically palatable synthesis of the unpalatable notion of simply refusing treatment unless they pay full cost .
7,8 PER|11,12 PER|15,16 PER|31,32 PER
7,8 PER|11,12 PER|15,16 PER|31,32 PER

They ' re basically buying future medical care throughout their lives , rather than eventually making the ( healthy ) remainder of the populace pay up .

Late filing of audited financial statements and earning restatements both factor into my External Reporting organizational indicator .
12,13 PER
12,13 PER

As a rule , I am wary of companies that do either of these things until I am confident that they have changed their standard business practices .
4,5 PER|8,9 ORG|9,10 ORG|16,17 PER|20,21 ORG|23,24 ORG
4,5 PER|8,9 ORG|9,10 ORG|16,17 PER|20,21 ORG|23,24 ORG

19,20 PER|29,30 ORG
19,20 PER|29,30 ORG

2005 - 01 - 08T13 : 23 : 00



It is just about time for Fortune magazine to release its 2005 list of 100 Best Companies to Work For .
6,8 ORG|10,11 ORG|16,17 ORG
6,8 ORG|10,11 ORG|16,17 ORG

So now is a good time to ask a simple question : Why should we care ?
14,15 PER
14,15 PER

Making this list is certainly a source of pride .



It can also be helpful if you are looking for a nice new job .
6,7 PER|12,13 Personnel:Start-Position|6,13 r_Person
6,7 PER|12,13 Personnel:Start-Position|6,13 r_Person

Should anyone else pay attention to this list ?
1,2 PER
1,2 PER

Well , thanks for asking because I just happen to have an answer for that question .
6,7 PER
6,7 PER

It turns out that investors can benefit by paying attention to this list as well .
4,5 PER
4,5 PER

In a study published in the Journal of Business Finance & Accoun ting ( 2003 , 30 : 771 - 798 ), Greg Filbeck and Dianna Preece found that companies on the Fortune list of 100 Best Companies to Work For outperformed a matched sample of firms along multiple measures of return .
6,12 ORG|22,24 PER|25,27 PER|29,30 ORG|32,33 ORG|37,38 ORG|44,45 ORG|46,47 ORG
6,12 ORG|22,24 PER|25,27 PER|29,30 ORG|32,33 ORG|37,38 ORG|44,45 ORG|46,47 ORG

This study is particularly relevant for investors because the authors measured return after the list was announced .
6,7 PER|9,10 PER
6,7 PER|9,10 PER

To often these studies use as a starting point the moment before information becomes public .



The only way to benefit from such information is by holding the stock before the information becomes public .



This study indicates that the Best Companies to Work For information may still be useful even after the information becomes public .
6,7 ORG
6,7 ORG

It might also be useful to look at companies that have consistently made the list in the previous few years and make an educated guess about their inclusion on this year ' s list .
8,9 ORG|9,10 ORG|26,27 ORG
8,9 ORG|9,10 ORG|26,27 ORG

Search the news archives and see if in the past year the company did anything that might have totally pissed off their employees .
12,13 ORG|21,22 ORG|22,23 PER
12,13 ORG|21,22 ORG|22,23 PER

Massive layoffs , bitter union battles , stopped offering free massages , etc .
4,5 ORG
4,5 ORG

You might also want to be wary if the CEO or a bunch of other top executives have been replaced .
0,1 PER|9,10 PER|12,13 PER|16,17 PER|19,20 Personnel:End-Position|9,20 r_Person|12,20 r_Person
0,1 PER|9,10 PER|12,13 PER|16,17 PER|19,20 Personnel:End-Position|9,20 r_Person|12,20 r_Person

That can often generate a period of uncertainty in a workforce .
10,11 PER
10,11 PER

Byrne

2005 - 02 - 04T13 : 22 : 00



It ' s always difficult to get used to a central fact of the modern economy : The best new technology will keep getting better at an absolutely astounding rate .



Usually , the improvement curve flattens pretty fast -- the usual auto industry / computer industry comparison works just fine ( According to the standard urban legend , Bill Gates notes that " If we ' d been making cars instead of software , you ' d get 500 miles to the gallon , need an oil change every 250 , 000 miles , and be able to replace your car for $ 200 ," to which a mythical GM executive replies " Ah , but if Microsoft made cars , they ' d crash three times a day , too !
11,12 VEH|12,13 ORG|15,16 ORG|28,30 PER|34,35 ORG|39,40 VEH|44,45 PER|69,70 PER|70,71 VEH|79,80 ORG|80,81 PER|87,88 ORG|89,90 VEH|91,92 VEH
11,12 VEH|12,13 ORG|15,16 ORG|28,30 PER|34,35 ORG|39,40 VEH|44,45 PER|69,70 PER|70,71 VEH|79,80 ORG|80,81 PER|87,88 ORG|89,90 VEH|91,92 VEH

").



Anyway , a few announcements during the last two days underscore the fact that the growth in memory and processing power for computers is far from over : Hewlett - Packard is developing a new replacement for the transistor , and a consortium of software companies is backing a new technology that would allow discs to hold up to a terabyte of information .
28,31 ORG|42,43 ORG|45,46 ORG
28,31 ORG|42,43 ORG|45,46 ORG

No idea where this will end up : It ' s not altogether rare that these announcements result in a very expensive project to develop something that , for whatever reason , isn ' t worthwhile to consumers .
37,38 PER
37,38 PER

But it ' s important to remember that the status quo is never more than a snapshot -- investing as though it ' s permanent is a recipe for disaster .

0,1 PER
0,1 PER

Instead , a menu of options may be considered , including installing infrared ( IR ) countermeasures on aircraft ; modifying flight operations and air traffic control procedures ; improving airport and regional security ; and strengthening missile non - proliferation efforts .
18,19 VEH|30,31 FAC|37,38 WEA
18,19 VEH|30,31 FAC|37,38 WEA

1,2 VEH|3,4 WEA|9,10 VEH|14,15 LOC|15,16 LOC
1,2 VEH|3,4 WEA|9,10 VEH|14,15 LOC|15,16 LOC

However , this option has a relatively high cost , between $ 1 million and $ 3 million per aircraft , and the time needed for implementation does not allow for immediate response to the existing terrorist threat .
19,20 VEH|36,37 PER
19,20 VEH|36,37 PER

Procedural improvements such as specific flight crew training , altering air traffic procedures to minimize exposure to the threat , and improved security near airports may be less costly than countermeasures and could more immediately help deter domestic terrorist attacks .

Maurice R . " Hank " Greenberg , who turns 80 in May , groomed two sons to be successors , but both have since left AIG . Greenberg Sr . then created an office of the chairman in 2002 , which includes co - COOs Martin J . Sullivan and Donald P . Kanak .
0,7 PER|8,9 PER|16,17 PER|19,20 PER|22,23 PER|26,27 ORG|28,30 PER|34,35 PER|37,38 PER|41,42 PER|43,46 PER|46,50 PER|51,55 PER|25,26 Personnel:End-Position|22,26 r_Person|25,27 Entity

Perhaps this is a good time for a quick refresher ....



The CEO works for the board ... end lesson .
1,2 PER|5,6 PER
1,2 PER|5,6 PER

I guess it is not as straight forward when your CEO is also chairman and one of the largest shareholders .
0,1 PER|9,10 PER|10,11 PER|13,14 PER|15,16 PER|19,20 PER
0,1 PER|9,10 PER|10,11 PER|13,14 PER|15,16 PER|19,20 PER

It would be tempting to get on my high horse right now about the need to separate the positions of CEO and Chairman but to be honest with you I don ' t really believe that .
7,8 PER|20,21 PER|22,23 PER|28,29 PER|29,30 PER
7,8 PER|20,21 PER|22,23 PER|28,29 PER|29,30 PER

I know CEO / chair duality is a popular cause for corporate governance .
0,1 PER|2,3 PER|4,5 PER
0,1 PER|2,3 PER|4,5 PER

However there is little empirical evidence to suggest that separating these roles affects firm performance in either a positive or negative way .



Having a combined CEO / Chairman does reduce the ability of the board to act as a check on management and this does mean that you need to be more critical in your assessment of the trustworthiness of the top management team .
3,6 PER|12,13 PER|19,20 PER|25,26 PER|32,33 PER|41,42 PER
3,6 PER|12,13 PER|19,20 PER|25,26 PER|32,33 PER|41,42 PER

This downside of having a combined CEO / chair is offset by ( 1 ) a reduction of coordination and communication costs at the top of the organization and ( 2 ) an increase in the negotiating position of the CEO when dealing with suppliers , potential merger partners , etc .
6,9 PER|40,41 PER|44,45 ORG|48,49 ORG
6,9 PER|40,41 PER|44,45 ORG|48,49 ORG

# 2 could be particularly useful in a dynamic industry .



I do however look more carefully at the top management team of a company with a CEO / Chair before investing .
0,1 PER|10,11 PER|13,14 ORG|16,19 PER
0,1 PER|10,11 PER|13,14 ORG|16,19 PER

It is important that you can get a sense of the trustworthiness of the CEO .
4,5 PER|14,15 PER
4,5 PER|14,15 PER

Is there high turnover among senior managers ?
6,7 PER|3,4 Personnel:End-Position|3,7 Person
6,7 PER|3,4 Personnel:End-Position|3,7 Person

Is there a record of regulatory problems ?



If the CEO is new , I also look at the performance of the CEO ' s previous company .
2,3 PER|6,7 PER|14,15 PER|18,19 ORG|17,18 Personnel:End-Position|14,18 r_Person|17,19 Entity
2,3 PER|6,7 PER|14,15 PER|18,19 ORG|17,18 Personnel:End-Position|14,18 r_Person|17,19 Entity

I am most concerned if the fortunes of the prior employer took a sudden turn for the worse after the CEO left .

2004 - 12 - 12T14 : 47 : 00



Conglomerates are a fascinating species : The standard definition is ' a company involved in multiple unrelated businesses ' but the more accurate definition would be ' a company that relies on financial pyrotechnics , balance sheet juggling , and adroit accounting to create the illusion of growth '.
0,1 ORG|4,5 ORG|12,13 ORG|28,29 ORG|29,30 ORG
0,1 ORG|4,5 ORG|12,13 ORG|28,29 ORG|29,30 ORG

I love to write about them , but I ' d hate to own one , since most of their market value comes from the market ' s assumption that the company ' s leaders will somehow find a way to retroactively justify their overvaluation .
0,1 PER|5,6 ORG|8,9 PER|14,15 ORG|19,20 ORG|31,32 ORG|34,35 PER|43,44 PER
0,1 PER|5,6 ORG|8,9 PER|14,15 ORG|19,20 ORG|31,32 ORG|34,35 PER|43,44 PER

Usually , it doesn ' t work , but when it does the results can be spectacularly entertaining .



For a while ( see Ling - Temco - Vought or Tyco for details ).
5,10 ORG|11,12 ORG
5,10 ORG|11,12 ORG

The recent rumors about WalMart ' s plans to buy out a shipping company have given rise to the fear that the company may go the conglomerate route .
4,5 ORG|13,14 ORG|22,23 ORG|26,27 ORG|9,11 Transaction:Transfer-Ownership|9,14 Artifact|10,14 Artifact|4,10 r_Buyer|4,11 r_Buyer
4,5 ORG|13,14 ORG|22,23 ORG|26,27 ORG|9,11 Transaction:Transfer-Ownership|9,14 Artifact|4,11 r_Buyer

They have many of the symptoms of a late - stage conglomerate : A gigantic main business with slowing growth , fear that competition will substantially reduce the profitability of their main business , a shareholder base that includes many people who own only WalMart stock ( thus providing another incentive for intracompany diversification ), and enough resources to pull it off on a grand scale .
0,1 ORG|11,12 ORG|30,31 ORG|35,36 PER|36,37 PER|37,38 PER|40,41 PER|41,42 PER|44,45 ORG
0,1 ORG|11,12 ORG|30,31 ORG|35,36 PER|36,37 PER|37,38 PER|40,41 PER|41,42 PER|44,45 ORG

I can understand the concerns , but I don ' t see the motivation .
0,1 PER|7,8 PER
0,1 PER|7,8 PER

As a retailer of just about everything , WalMart can expand into some pretty broadly - defined areas without going beyond either their core competencies or some arenas where they can cut costs .
2,3 ORG|8,9 ORG|22,23 ORG|29,30 ORG
2,3 ORG|8,9 ORG|22,23 ORG|29,30 ORG

After all , adding some international shipping assets to their holdings would be a natural extension of their enormously successful practice of buying the distribution network for their products .
9,10 ORG|17,18 ORG|27,28 ORG
9,10 ORG|17,18 ORG|27,28 ORG

They ' re coming close to Smithfield Food ' s very successful ' squeal to meal ' policy ; if these rumors are true , the result for shareholders will be a pretty positive one .
0,1 ORG|6,8 ORG|28,29 PER
0,1 ORG|6,8 ORG|28,29 PER

Frenetic merger and acquisition activity doesn ' t mean much in the early days of a business -- it ' s just as likely that ridiculously overfunded startups are buying out their bankrupt competitors to create larger and less stable conglomerates as it is that forward - thinking visionaries are cutting off their competitors early .

But when an outsider buys into the business once it ' s established itself as important , but before it ' s really gotten profitable , it ' s big news .

2004 - 12 - 11T18 : 45 : 00



Scrappy underdog Netflix had its day earlier in the year , when it became one of the hottest stocks around ( sporting an eye - popping P / E in the high 900 ' s on the way up , and , thanks to a poor earnings report , over 1 , 000 on the way down ).
1,2 ORG|2,3 ORG|4,5 ORG|12,13 ORG
1,2 ORG|2,3 ORG|4,5 ORG|12,13 ORG

There ' s plenty of argument about the future of DVD and video rental , and Netflix represents a pure - play on one of the three dominant hypotheses :
16,17 ORG
16,17 ORG

I .



That business is O - V - E - R -- Between pay - per - view , video - on - demand , pirated movies , high - bandwidth Internet broadcasts , and the increasing availability of other media , it takes some faith to see any future for movie rentals .
1,2 ORG|3,10 Business:End-Org|1,4 r_Org|1,5 r_Org|1,6 r_Org|1,7 r_Org|1,8 r_Org|1,9 r_Org|1,10 r_Org
1,2 ORG|3,10 Business:End-Org|1,10 r_Org

Those who don ' t have the requisite faith will point to these factors as proof that the business is dying and the movie business in general will need a pretty significant overhaul before it can make profits .
0,1 PER|1,2 PER|18,19 ORG|24,25 ORG|34,35 ORG
0,1 PER|1,2 PER|18,19 ORG|24,25 ORG|34,35 ORG

Movie rentals are no longer a cheap alternative to other ways of viewing films ; they ' re the stodgy , expensive way .



There aren ' t any pure - play buys on this theory , but someone who believes it might overweight their portfolio in cable companies -- if they purchased any media stocks at all .
14,15 PER|15,16 PER|20,21 PER|24,25 ORG|27,28 PER
14,15 PER|15,16 PER|20,21 PER|24,25 ORG|27,28 PER

Of course , there have been companies whose performance would perfectly mimic the validity of this idea , but Psuedo . com failed without producing a single show , and Broadcast . com was swallowed for $ 6 billion by Yahoo !, to Yahoo !
6,7 ORG|7,8 ORG|19,22 ORG|30,33 ORG|40,41 ORG|43,44 ORG|22,23 Business:End-Org|19,23 r_Org|20,23 r_Org|21,23 r_Org|34,35 Transaction:Transfer-Ownership|30,35 r_Artifact|31,35 r_Artifact|32,35 r_Artifact|34,41 Buyer
6,7 ORG|7,8 ORG|19,22 ORG|30,33 ORG|40,41 ORG|43,44 ORG|22,23 Business:End-Org|19,23 r_Org|34,35 Transaction:Transfer-Ownership|30,35 r_Artifact|34,41 Buyer

' s great regret .



II .



Not so fast -- it ' ll just go online !



-- Anyone who wants to counter that argument would probably start by taking us back to 1997 , when in terms of time used , text was the most popular kind of information online .
1,2 PER|2,3 PER|13,14 PER
1,2 PER|2,3 PER|13,14 PER

At the time , and for years after , people argued that the traditional bookstore would become obsolete .
9,10 PER|14,15 FAC
9,10 PER|14,15 FAC

After all , how could we stand for a rapaciously arborcidal medium like ' books ' or ' newspapers ' when we could transmit the same data as bits and bytes and save on transportation , too ?
5,6 PER|21,22 PER
5,6 PER|21,22 PER

As it turns out , of course , Amazon . com , BarnseandNoble . com , and a host of others simply took the bookstore model , attached a 56K modem , and declared themselves The Future .
8,11 ORG|12,15 ORG|18,19 ORG|24,25 FAC|34,35 ORG
8,11 ORG|12,15 ORG|18,19 ORG|24,25 FAC|34,35 ORG

Netflix is doing much the same thing : Taking the traditional business online to cut costs and boost customer service .
0,1 ORG|18,19 PER
0,1 ORG|18,19 PER

III .



Who d ' you think you ' re kidding ?
0,1 PER|3,4 PER|5,6 PER
0,1 PER|3,4 PER|5,6 PER

You can ' t kill movie rental stores -- So there ' s a big difference between movies and books : For books , the retail store is practically the sole medium of distribution ; if you don ' t sell through them , books won ' t get sold .
0,1 PER|7,8 ORG|26,27 FAC|31,32 FAC|36,37 PER|42,43 FAC
0,1 PER|7,8 ORG|26,27 FAC|31,32 FAC|36,37 PER|42,43 FAC

For movies , the video rental store is just one way to get videos out there ( though at 45 - 55 % of studio revenues , it ' s a much more important one than people think ).
6,7 ORG|24,25 ORG|27,28 ORG|34,35 ORG
6,7 ORG|24,25 ORG|27,28 ORG|34,35 ORG

But given the high valuations ascribed to bricks - and - mortar - and - dead tree booksellers like Barnes and Noble , Borders , and to a much lesser extent Books - A - Million , surely there ' s room for a Blockbuster , along with a Movie Gallery or two .
17,18 FAC|19,22 ORG|23,24 ORG|31,36 ORG|44,45 ORG|49,51 ORG
17,18 FAC|19,22 ORG|23,24 ORG|31,36 ORG|44,45 ORG|49,51 ORG

The latter , at least , still has room to grow .
1,2 ORG
1,2 ORG

By focusing on smaller , rural communities ( preferably the sort that considers DSL ' newfangled ') they ' re WalMarting WalMart -- competing with Walmart ' s awful in - store video rentals by offering better selection and much lower prices .
6,7 GPE|17,18 ORG|21,22 ORG|25,26 ORG|29,32 FAC
6,7 GPE|17,18 ORG|21,22 ORG|25,26 ORG|29,32 FAC

The movie business is changing dramatically as the potential for online distribution grows , but like every other business it leaves lots of room for traditional operators to operate at traditional ( read : high ) profits .
2,3 ORG|19,20 ORG
2,3 ORG|19,20 ORG

The aggressive bidding war for Hollywood Video , featuring two of their competitors , a buyout shop , and one of the savviest raiders around , is proof that some people still think these stores are worth something .
5,7 ORG|11,12 ORG|12,13 ORG|16,17 ORG|23,24 ORG|30,31 PER|34,35 ORG
5,7 ORG|11,12 ORG|12,13 ORG|16,17 ORG|23,24 ORG|30,31 PER|34,35 ORG

And I ' m one of them .
1,2 PER|4,5 PER|6,7 PER
1,2 PER|4,5 PER|6,7 PER

2,4 ORG|5,6 GPE|6,7 PER|14,15 WEA|19,20 WEA|21,22 PER|25,26 PER|27,28 PER|30,31 ORG|33,34 PER

5,6 PER|13,14 WEA|14,15 PER|17,18 PER|18,19 FAC|20,21 ORG

9,10 WEA|10,11 PER|11,12 ORG
